Brand History


BYU-Idaho's visualidentityhas been evolving since the school was founded. In our Ricks College days, images such as the Viking ship, the mighty oak, the Teton peak and the Viking warrior were all recognized icons and symbolic to the development of the college. Now, as BYU-Idaho continues to evolve as a world-class institution, there is an increasing need for more consistency and greater quality and coordination in visual and written communication.


Our new visualidentitystandards are intended to assist in unifying the campus and establishing a method that will allow each campus entity to have a voice of its own, while contributing positively to the BYU-Idaho brand. Our overall goal is to achieve a consistent appearance so that we can create cohesion, emerge out of obscurity, and build our reputation around the world.


By understanding BYU-Idaho's brand history, we can better realize the need for a set of guidelines as we direct our efforts toward the future.


The importance of brandidentityat BYU-Idaho has increased in recent years. In the past, it was not as important to focus on the world-class nature of our efforts but instead on the warm and welcoming feel of the small town. As our charge to rise in stature has come, the need for greater quality and coordination has accompanied the challenges of physical growth. Now more than ever, a consistent and clear brandidentityis crucial to the communication of our message. By increasing our level of adherence to these standards, we are able to continue to project the warm and welcoming spirit of our campus in a professional way.


Where the Current Brand Comes From

In describing the various aspects of the BYU-Idaho brand, it is helpful to remember that our identity is part of a larger system that was given to us through the Church Educational System (CES), and that our sister institutions share many of the same characteristics with slight variations.
